instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> water damaged , no 20v boost replaced <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> 4 ic. any help[ATTACH type="full"]60296[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

All 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips affected by liquid?

Post voltage and diode mode to ground at LDO rails of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> at least?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Actually <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> not affected by water. See picture. Only corner area . Water . I cleaned well . Checked any resistance  disconnect. All good. And all boltages on 4 cd ics fine. I double checked, gr value also fine. ( injave an working board copared gr ok).  4 ports 5v looping. . Same issies have 2 boards.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>. Yes 3.4v fine. Ldo 3.3 and 1.8 b on 4 cd ic  fine. Smc 3.3 amd 1.8 and 1.2 fine . Smc reset fine.  There is no 12 b temporary. Even .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Please, take your time and write correctly.
We need to understand you, if need help.

You've replaced the 4 chips, even not affected by liquid, why?
So you get now 1V1 <SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> on each chip?

Check diode mode to ground at F7000/1; be sure the fuses are good.
Connect known good battery (with some charge) and check voltage again.
Check if board tries to turn on in this case.
Also check if USB-C ports switch to 20V, if battery is present.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
1V1 <SIGNAL>LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> on each chip yes its  present , with battery will update tomorrow.. no short on f7000, and fuses good.

CAN I USE POWER SUPPLY 12V INSTED OF BATTERY?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
No, try its battery first.
But need to test with known good one, which also holds some charge.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: when i connect with charging battery . its loping 20v, and current draw 0v, fan spin speed .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
If fan spins, check voltage on big coils.
Measure L7211 start voltage and after 10-15s, if present.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: fan spin fast,then stop, 0v on l7211

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Try to catch voltage when fan spins.
Check if voltage tries at least to appear at L7900/60, L7330 and L7211.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
L7900 voltage should appear before fan starts to spin even.
Check diode mode to ground there.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> should be present.

Remember to check when fan spins...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>  <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Sorry . Actually 1.1 ldo very low on one chip. I replaced that cd . Now machine working. Thanks for your great support.
